importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks when the Amazon cloud outage was reported as resolved, highlighting the timing of a major technological disruption in the digital infrastructure.
The outage began early Monday morning and was resolved by 6 p.m. Eastern time on the same day, indicating a full-day disruption that culminated in resolution by late afternoon.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage began at approximately 3:11 a.m. and lasted through the day, with services returning to normal by 6 p.m. Eastern, illustrating the duration and impact of a critical cloud service failure.
At Ohio State University, access to online materials was restored by 7:10 p.m. Eastern, showing the timeline of recovery for educational institutions dependent on AWS.

keyTakeAways: A massive outage of Amazon Web Services (AWS) disrupted internet access globally, affecting social media, gaming, financial services, streaming platforms, and education.
The outage was traced to issues in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which converts web addresses into IP addresses, a critical infrastructure element.

Many high-profile services—Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, Signal, and Canvas—were impacted, demonstrating how reliant modern society is on a small number of cloud providers.
Educational platforms such as Canvas, used by 50% of college and university students in North America, including all Ivy League schools, were unable to function, disrupting learning and grading.

Cybersecurity experts note that while such outages are common and usually resolve within hours, they expose a vulnerability: the world’s digital infrastructure depends on a few major companies, making it fragile when failures occur.
The AWS outage is not unprecedented—similar events occurred in 2017, 2020, 2021, and 2023—indicating a recurring pattern of reliance and fragility in cloud-based systems.
Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess describe recovery as a 'slow and bumpy' process, similar to post-power-outage restoration, with intermittent glitches during repairs.
There is no evidence of a cyberattack; the issue is attributed to a technical failure in AWS's DNS infrastructure, not malicious activity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) suffered a major global outage on October 20, 2025, beginning around 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and lasting through the day. The disruption stemmed from issues in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which is essential for translating web addresses into IP addresses. As a result, numerous online services—including social media platforms like Snapchat and Roblox, financial apps like Robinhood, streaming services such as Netflix and Disney+, and educational platforms like Canvas—became inaccessible. Students at universities including the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, University of California, Riverside, and Ohio State University were unable to access coursework or submit assignments. Amazon confirmed that services were restored by 6 p.m. Eastern time, though engineers reported intermittent issues during recovery. Cybersecurity experts, including Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess, noted that such outages are common and typically resolve within hours, with no evidence of a cyberattack. This incident underscores the growing fragility of the internet, which increasingly depends on a small number of technology companies like Amazon to maintain core infrastructure.
title: Amazon Cloud Outage Exposes Internet’s Vulnerable Backbone
